answers.answer: Your TPOab result is close to the top of the range, but on diagnosis of Hashi's, many of us have TPOab in the high hundreds, or even thousands.  TPOab can be somewhat elevated with other autoimmune diseases as well.So, as your TSH numbers have been dropping, have you acquired more and more hyper symptoms?  What are your symptoms?We do need FT3 and FT4 to really know what might be going on.

Hopefully I CAN GET Those RESULTS monday.I seem to have hypo symptoms,  it also runs in my family. Fatigued,  terrible mornings,  losing hair like crazy, terrible dry skin problems. Gain weight effortlessly. ..losing is so hard, watch carbs, calories use activity monitor,  walk an hour every other day.I do have other autoimmune disease though. Crohn's,  and APS of my blood.And was diagnosed with fibromyalgia so I don't know. .. :(

Well, if your symptoms are worsening hypo symptoms with your TSH going down, we have to start thinking about secondary hypothyroidism.  This is actually a pituitary dysfunction, where the pituitary doesn't put out enough TSH to stimulate the thyroid to produce hormone.  The result is an underactive thyroid, even though the root cause is pituitary.Your other AI diseases could be raising your TPOab.Do you know the cause of the rest of your family's hypo?

Hi! I'm  not sure the reasons with my family's history,y grandma and Aunt have passed.I did get my T4 results today, low.5.9 lab normal  6.2-14.6He did not perform T3 or any other tests.I'm just thinking maybe I should see an endocrinologist?  Have not had much faith in my PCP unfortunately.

Your T4, which is total T4, is below range.  This tells us that your thyroid is not producing enough hormone.  Furthermore ranges for T3 and T4 are very flawed, and most of us found we didn't feel well until T4 was about the middle of the range and T3 the upper half of range.  So, what at first glance looks just a little low is worse than it appears.With below range T4, we would expect your TSH to be much higher than it is.  So, secondary hypothyroidism is highly probable.Do you think your PCP would agree to treat you?What you should try to find is a good thyroid doctor.  Unfortunately, being an endo doesn't guarantee that a doctor is a good thyroid doctor.  Many endos are only interested in treating diabetes and don't really keep up on thyroid.  It usually pays to interview them over the phone a bit before making an appointment.  At least, you can rule out the worst of the worst that way.  I can give you some suggestions on what to ask if you're interested.

Thank you so much! Yes I would love direction on how to pick a good thyroid doctor.I called my PCP after posting earlier....he stated that since my TSH is within normal range even though it's low-it doesn't matter that my T4 is low, I need no further testing, or specialist!It makes me so angry! I feel most doctors don't listen and don't care.I do believe I do not need a referral with my insurance.

Unfortunately, most doctors think TSH is the ultimate in thyroid testing.  That couldn't be further from the truth, but you can't convince them of that.You'll probably have to interview the doctor through a nurse.  An especially rabid receptionist will probably try to keep you away from the nurses, too, but that usually only lasts until she realizes she has no clue how to answer your question.  The first question I'd ask is which tests the doctor usually orders for his hypo patients.  You want to hear FT3, FT4 and TSH.  If they say they only order TSH...run!Another good question is which meds they are open to using.  Some doctors are "T4 only" (Synthroid, Levoxyl and generics) people, some will use both synthetic T3 (Cytomel and generics) and synthetic T4, and some will use desiccated porcine thyroid (Armour, NatureThroid, Erfa, just to name a few) as well.  These are our three basic treatment options, and it's really great when a doctor is open to all three.  Practically speaking, however, most fall into either the synthetic or the desiccated camp.  Steer clear of the ones who only use T4.You can also ask if they treat mostly diabetes.I agree most don't listen and/or don't care.  Their chief concern is staying out of litigation.  Symptoms are subjective.  So, they can cover their backsides by refusing to treat if your numbers are in range.  Unfortunately, in their last joint position paper, AACE and ATA reaffirmed that TSH was the gold standard in thyroid testing.  So, if your TSH is in range, they're perfectly justified in denying treatment.

Thank you so much!I did talk to my uncle,  he wasn't sure why grandma had the problems,  my aunt was put on synthetic at 15 because of goiter, and he has been on it for 20 years, just says he has hypothyroidism  lol. My grandmother took it for years as well!

question: Hi, my a-TPO results came back 57.3, with lab normal being  <60.  My TSH is .68 lab normal .368-5. My TSH numbers have been progressively dropping for 2 yrs-started at a4!I asked Dr to do t3& t4 also, but did not get any results for them and can't call to inquire until monday...It just seems I'm right on the brink of abnormal, and with so many symptoms.  Any ideas or thoughts out there?
title: A-TPO results.
